fields: On the basis of nourishment acquisition, organisms are classifed as {{c1::autotrophs}} (e.g. plants) or {{c1::heterotrophs}} (e.g. animals)

troph - "nourishment"

Carbon source:
autotroph: CO2
heterotroph: organic carbons


Autotrophs can use energy from sunlight or other energy sources to convert inorganic CO2 into organic compounds. Heterotrophs are unable to do this and must take in organic carbon, typically by eating autotrophs or other heterotrophs.
The components of a bacterial flagellum (lengthwise) are {{c1::basal body (kinetosome)}}, {{c1::hook}}, and {{c1::filament}}.
compare to cilium
The three domains of life are {{c1::Archaea}}, {{c1::Bacteria}}, and {{c1::Eukarya}}

The taxonomical heirarchy is, top to bottom:

{{c1::Domain
Kingdom
Phylum (Division)*
Class
Order
Family
Genus
Species}}

* phylum is used in the kingdom Animalia and important protozoans

Also have subspecies based on: phenotype, serotype, biotype.



Mnemonic: Dear King Philip Came Over For Good Soup
The current taxonomic system now has eight levels in its hierarchy, from lowest to highest, they are: species, genus, family, order, class, phylum, kingdom, and domain. 
-- https://opentextbc.ca/biology/chapter/1-1-themes-and-concepts-of-biology/

The kingdoms under each taxonomic domain are:

Archaea: {{c1::archaea}}
Bacteria: {{c1::eubacteria}}
Eukaria: {{c1::animalia, plantae, protista, and fungi}}
{{c1::Ecological niche}} is the range of environmental conditions and resources that matches a species' persistence
{{c1::True}} pathogens can cause disease in virtually any susceptible host
{{c1::Opportunistic}} pathogens rarely cause disease in individual unless immunocompromised

Are parasites unicellular or multicellular?

{{c1::either :)}}

Are fungi unicellular or multicellular?

{{c1::either but mostly multicellular}}

Do fungi reproduce sexually or asexually?

{{c1::Either or both}}
{{c1::Hyphae}} are filamentous structures that comprise the vegetative part of a fungus, the {{c1::mycelium (or shiro)}}

Are hyphae visible to the naked eye?

{{c1::No. but mycelia are.}}
Based on presence of cell walls*, true hyphae are classified as either {{c1::septate}}, {{c1::aseptate (coenocytic)}}

*depends on cell division, if nucleus but not cytoplasm divides, then aseptate



Septate:
genus Aspergillus
class Basidiomycetes
class Asomycetes

Aseptate:
genus Mucor
division Zygomycetes
Add:https://www.google.com/amp/s/pediaa.com/difference-between-hyphae-and-pseudohyphae/amp/
{{c1::True}} yeasts aka {{c2::budding}} yeasts do not form hyphae
They reproduce asexully = budding
Whereas eukaryotic DNA is complexed with histones (and other proteins), prokaryotic DNA are complexed with {{c1::RNA}}

make card out of table below

{{c1::a}}
{{c1::Dimorphic}} fungi can grow either as true yeast or in filamentous form (i.e. w/ hyphae)
Viruses are {{c1::obligate parasites}}, they require host cells for replication

aka holoparasite

increase in number does not involve mitosis, meiosis, or binary fission

Do viruses increase in size (i.e. grow)?

{{c1::No.}}
The {{c1::epithet}} refers to the species within the genus to which it belongs
Family names of bacteria end with the suffix {{c1::-aceae}}
not entirely sure

Species may be subdivided into subspecies based on differences in:

{{c1::1. Phenotype (subsp.)
2. Serotype (serovar)
3. Biotype (biovar)::3}}
>try looking for examples
Domain archaea is metabolically closer to the domain: {{c1::bacteria}}

Morphologically: bacteria
Metabolically: bacteria
Phylogenetically: eukarya


https://www.quora.com/Why-do-biologists-place-Archaea-closer-to-the-Eukarya-Domain-even-though-they-are-considered-prokaryotes
The relationship between the three domains is of central importance for understanding the origin of life. Most of the metabolic pathways, which are the object of the majority of an organism's genes, are common between Archaea and Bacteria, while most genes involved in genome expression are common between Archaea and Eukarya. . . .
The evolutionary relationship between archaea and eukaryotes remains unclear. Aside from the similarities in cell structure and function that are discussed below, many genetic trees group the two.
Complicating factors include claims that the relationship between eukaryotes and the archaeal phylum Crenarchaeota is closer than the relationship between the Euryarchaeota and the phylum Crenarchaeota and the presence of archaea-like genes in certain bacteria, such as Thermotoga maritima, from horizontal gene transfer. The standard hypothesis states that the ancestor of the eukaryotes diverged early from the Archaea, and that eukaryotes arose through fusion of an archaean and eubacterium, which became the nucleus and cytoplasm; this hypothesis explains various genetic similarities but runs into difficulties explaining cell structure. An alternative hypothesis, the eocyte hypothesis, posits that Eukaryota emerged relatively late from the Archaea.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Archaea
Domain archaea is phylogenetically closer to the domain: {{c1::eukarya}}

Morphologically: bacteria
Metabolically: bacteria
Phylogenetically: eukaryotes


https://www.quora.com/Why-do-biologists-place-Archaea-closer-to-the-Eukarya-Domain-even-though-they-are-considered-prokaryotes
The relationship between the three domains is of central importance for understanding the origin of life. Most of the metabolic pathways, which are the object of the majority of an organism's genes, are common between Archaea and Bacteria, while most genes involved in genome expression are common between Archaea and Eukarya. . . .
The evolutionary relationship between archaea and eukaryotes remains unclear. Aside from the similarities in cell structure and function that are discussed below, many genetic trees group the two.
Complicating factors include claims that the relationship between eukaryotes and the archaeal phylum Crenarchaeota is closer than the relationship between the Euryarchaeota and the phylum Crenarchaeota and the presence of archaea-like genes in certain bacteria, such as Thermotoga maritima, from horizontal gene transfer. The standard hypothesis states that the ancestor of the eukaryotes diverged early from the Archaea, and that eukaryotes arose through fusion of an archaean and eubacterium, which became the nucleus and cytoplasm; this hypothesis explains various genetic similarities but runs into difficulties explaining cell structure. An alternative hypothesis, the eocyte hypothesis, posits that Eukaryota emerged relatively late from the Archaea.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Archaea
Domain archaea is morphologically closer to the domain: {{c1::bacteria (both prokaryotes)}}

Morphologically: bacteria
Metabolically: bacteria
Phylogenetically: eukaryotes


https://www.quora.com/Why-do-biologists-place-Archaea-closer-to-the-Eukarya-Domain-even-though-they-are-considered-prokaryotes
The relationship between the three domains is of central importance for understanding the origin of life. Most of the metabolic pathways, which are the object of the majority of an organism's genes, are common between Archaea and Bacteria, while most genes involved in genome expression are common between Archaea and Eukarya. . . .
The evolutionary relationship between archaea and eukaryotes remains unclear. Aside from the similarities in cell structure and function that are discussed below, many genetic trees group the two.
Complicating factors include claims that the relationship between eukaryotes and the archaeal phylum Crenarchaeota is closer than the relationship between the Euryarchaeota and the phylum Crenarchaeota and the presence of archaea-like genes in certain bacteria, such as Thermotoga maritima, from horizontal gene transfer. The standard hypothesis states that the ancestor of the eukaryotes diverged early from the Archaea, and that eukaryotes arose through fusion of an archaean and eubacterium, which became the nucleus and cytoplasm; this hypothesis explains various genetic similarities but runs into difficulties explaining cell structure. An alternative hypothesis, the eocyte hypothesis, posits that Eukaryota emerged relatively late from the Archaea.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Archaea
Archaeal cell wall is different from that of bacteria in that it lacks {{c1::peptidoglycan}}
pseudopeptidoglycan
{{c1::Methanogens}} are <u>extremophiles</u> who metabolize {{c2::H}} and {{c2::CO2}} to produce {{c2::CH4}}
{{c1::Nuclear bodies}} are membraneless structures that carry out nuclear functions
e.g., genome of bacteria (?)
{{c1::Mesosome}} is a bacterial organelle that appears as a plasma membrane {{c2::infold}} and aids in cellular respiration
The nuclear body of bacteria are attached to a {{c1::mesosome}}

Svedberg values are not additive because...

{{c1::there is loss of surface area}}

eukaryotes: 60S + 40S = 80S
prokaryotes: 50S + 30S = 70S

Go back to spores and endospores 

{{c1::p.7 Mahon}}
Most {{c1::pro}}karyotic plasma membrane lacks {{c2::sterols}}

except for Mycoplasma spp. (see existing AnKing cards)

still contains PL and proteins

hb Ureaplasma? lacks cell walls but do they also have sterols?
Prokaryotes have a {{c1::high}} osmotic pressure inside the cell
PM and cell walls prevent lysis?
{{c1::Peptidoglycan}} is aka {{c2::murein}}

What is the glycosidic linkage between NAM and NAG (peptidoglycan/murein)

{{c1::β(1→4)}}

The tetrapeptides attached to NAM residues of peptidoglycans can contain (discussed):

{{c1::1. L-alanine
2. D-glutamate
3. Meso-diaminopimelate
4. D-alanine}}
this may vary among species
The tetrapeptides in peptidoglycans attach to the {{c2::carboxyl}} group of the NAM residue
The tetrapeptides attached on NAM of peptidoglycans are cross-linked via a {{c1::peptide bridge}}
size of peptide bridge varies from 3 to 5 AAs
Antibiotics targetting peptidoglycan synthesis are more effective against Gram-{{c1::positive}} bacteria
In Gram + bacterial cell wall, <u>{{c1::teichoic}} acid</u> is anchored to the <u>{{c2::peptidoglycan}} </u>
In Gram + bacterial cell wall, {{c1::lipoteichoic}} acid is anchored to the {{c2::plasma membrane}}

The lipopolysaccharides in the outer membrane of Gram - bacteria 3 regions:

{{c1::1. O-specific polysaccharide (O antigen)
2. Core polysaccharide (outer and inner)
3. Lipid A (aka endotoxin)}}

What is responsible for fever and shock caused by infection from Gram negative bacteria?

{{c1::Lipid A of lipopolysaccharides}}

IL-1 and 6 = fever
TNFα = fever and hypotension
Nitric oxide = hypotension
The Gram negative bacteria's outer membrane is a barrier against hydro-{{c1::phobic}} compounds but allows hydro-{{c1::philic}} compounds via {{c2::porins}}
The {{c1::periplasm}} is the space between a Gram - bacteria's {{c2::outer membrane}} and {{c2::(inner) cell membrane}}. It contains the {{c3::peptidoglycan}} layer
Acid-fast bacteria are Gram {{c1::positive}}
but they stain poorly due to high levels of glycolipids and mycolic acid in its cell wall
{{c1:: L-form bacteria}} are bacteria that normally posses a cell wall but has lost it.

distinct from Mycoplasma spp.

can happen to both Gram + and -
Capsules and {{c2::Slime layers}} of bacteria are typically made of {{c1::water}} and {{c1::polysaccharide}} protecting against phagocytosis

can also be made of polypeptides

in some cases, functions also to aid in adherence to host tissue or synthetic implants.

see AnKing card

Compare:
1. Plasma membrane: phospholipids
2. Cell wall:
2a. Peptidoglycan: peptidoglycan
2b. Outer membrane: phospholipids
3. Capsule: water and polyasccharides
4. Slime layer: water and polysaccharides
5. Capsid: proteins

*polysaccharide = glycan
Antigens located in a bacteria's {{c2::cell wall}} are called {{c1::somatic antigens}}
Antigens located in a bacteria's capsule are called {{c1::capsular antigens}}
{{c1::Gram or india ink::stain}} stained organisms that possess a {{c3::capsule}} would display a {{c2::clear halo}} around it against the background material
not all bacteria have capsule (made of water and polysachharide)
{{c1::Gram or india ink::stain}} stained bacteria that possess a capsule would display a {{c2::halo}} between it and the background material
Capsules {{c1::increases}} a bacteria's virulence
inhibits phagocytosis

Flagella can be arranged in a cell in multiple ways:

Polar:
{{c1::1. Monotrichous
2. Amphitrichous
3. Lophotrichous
4. Amphilophotrichous}}

Nonpolar:
{{c1::5. Peritrichous}}

Cell appendages of a bacteria:

{{c1::Flagella}} - {{c2::motility::function}}
{{c1::Conjugation pili}} - {{c2::DNA exchange::function}}
{{c1::Fimbriae (normal pili)}} - {{c2::adhesion::function}}
eukaryotes do not have conjugation pili nor fimbriae

Do prokaryotes have cilia?

{{c1::No}}
{{c1::Chitin}} is the unique <u>structural component</u> of {{c2::fungal}} cell walls

plant cell walls have no chitin. = cellulose and lignin

fungal cell wall also contains: mannan, glucan.
Bacilli with tapered pointed ends are termed {{c1::fusiform}}
The alignment of bacillus bacteria is called {{c1::palisading}}
A(n) {{c1::pleomorphic}} bacterium displays different shapes and sizes <u>within a pure culture</u>
2 common: Rickettsia and Chlamydia
Short bacillus bacteria are known as {{c1::coccobacilli}}
Spiral or helical bacteria are known as {{c1::Spirochetes}}
vary in number of helical turns

Safranin (30 secs)::counterstain

rinse w/ water between every step

In gram staining, why is Gram - decolorized but not Gram +

{{c1::Decolorizers also degrades the outer membrane (and the thin peptidoglycan layer cannot contain crystal violet-iodine complex)}}

Does safranin stain Gram + or Gram - bacteria?

{{c1::Both. But safranin is not visible in Gram +}}
Cells in a direct smear from a <u>patient specimen</u>* should appear Gram-{{c1::negative}}
* epithelial cells, WBC, RBC, background material

Carbolfuchsin (red)::primary stain
Heat or Detergent*::mordant
Acidified alcohol::Decolorizer
Methylene blue::counterstain
Acid-fast Stain

*
Ziehl-Neelsen method = use heat
Kinyoun method (cold method) = use detergent

...

Carbolfuchsin (red)

{{c21::Methylene blue::counterstain}}
In the {{c1::Ziehl-Neelsen}} method of acid-fast staining, <u>heat</u> is used as a mordant

Ziehl-Neelsen method = use heat
Kinyoun method (cold method) = use detergent
In the {{c1::Kinyoun}} method of acid-fast staining, <u>a detergent </u>is used as a mordant

Ziehl-Neelsen method = use heat
Kinyoun method (cold method) = use detergent
{{c1::Auramine-rhodamine}} is a fluorochrome selective to {{c2::acid-fast}} bacteria and appears yellow/orange under UV

3 major nutritional needs for bacterial growth

{{c1::1. Carbon
2. Nitrogen
3. Energy source (ATP)}}

carbon 50% of DW - for making cellular constituents
nitrogen 14% of DW - for making proteins
ATP - for cellular functions

DW = dry weight

In smaller amounts:
1. Phosphate (for nucleic acids)
2. Phospholipids (for membrane)
3. Sulfur (for proteins)
4. Ions (Na+ K+ Cl- Ca2+)
Autotrophs that gain energy <u>photosynthetically</u> are called {{c1::phototrophs}}
autotrophs: able to grow simply, using carbon dioxide as the sole source of carbon
Autotrophs that gain energy by oxidation of organic compounds are called {{c1::chemolithotrophs}}
autotrophs: able to grow simply, using carbon dioxide as the sole source of carbon

Are all bacteria inhabiting the human body heterotrophs?

{{c1::Yes. All.}}
Chlamydia spp. are {{c1::obligate intracellular}} bacteria, they must be grown on tissue culture

{{c1::Anaerobic::aerobic/anaeorobic}} bacteria are more difficult to cultivate

*bonus: why?

fastidious and difficult to isolate

also Haemophilus influenzae (a facultative anaerobic capnophilic pathogen)
{{c1::Minimal}} culture media contains simple and completely defined components
Not usually used in diagnostic microbiology labs
{{c1::Nutrient}} culture media contains sources of nitrogen and amino acids (e.g. {{c2::meat extracts}}, {{c2::soybean extracts}})
{{c2::Colistin-nalidixic acid}} Agar is a selective media for Gram {{c1::positive}} bacteria as it disrupts cell membranes of Gram {{c1::negatives}} and blocks its DNA replication

Colistin and nalidixic acid : disrupt cell membrane

Nalidixic acid : block DNA replication
{{c1::Transport}} culture media preseves the viability of microogranisms to allow for delay
e.g., Stuart Broth; Amies and Cary Blair

3 environmental factors influence the growth rate of bacteria

{{c1::1. pH
2. Temperature
3. Gaseous composition of atmosphere}}
idcrowdchange
Most pathogenic bacteria grow best at {{c1::neutral}} pH
Diagnostic laboratory media for bacteria are usually adjusted to a final pH between 7.0 and 7.5
{{c1::Psychrophiles}} are bacteria that grow best at {{c2::cold}} temperatures (optimal T: {{c2::10°C–20°C::range in °C}})
{{c1::Mesophiles}} are bacteria that grow best at {{c2::moderate}} temperatures (optimal T: {{c2::20°C–40°C::range in °C}})
most bacteria that have adapted to humans are mesophiles (37°C)
{{c1::Thermophiles}} are bacteria that grow best at {{c2::high}} temperatures (optimal T: {{c2::50°C–60°C::range in °C}})
{{c1::Capnophilic}} organisms grow best when atmosphere is enrinched with CO<sub>2</sub> ({{c2::5%–10%::range in %}})
e.g. H. influenzae
{{c1::Microaerophilic}} bacteria require a reduced level of oxygen to grow (otherwise suffers oxidative stress)
e.g., Campylobacter spp. (require 5%–6% O2)

How do prokaryotes reproduce?

{{c1::binary fission::specific}}

Bacterial cell count can be done in 3 ways:

1. {{c1::Direct counting under microscope}}
2. {{c2::Direct plate count}}
3. {{c3::Density measurement}}

*bonus: describe answer

What type of bacteria carry out fermentation?

{{c1::Obligate anaerobes, aerotolerant anaerobes, and facultative anaerobes}}

What type of bacteria carry out aerobic respiration?

{{c1::Obligate aerobes and facultative anaerobes}}
The final electron acceptors in anaerobes are either: {{c1::an organic compound}}, {{c2::nitrate}}, or {{c3::sulfate}}
If the end product of lactic fermentation include other substances (e.g., CO2, alcohols, formic acid, and acetic acid) it said to be {{c1::heterolactic}}
if lactic acid only = homolactic (e.g., Lactobacillus spp.)

Enumerate some fermentation pathways used by microbes inhabiting the human body:

A: {{c1::alcoholic fermentation}}
L: {{c1::(homo/hetero) Lactic fermentation}}
P: {{c1::proprionic acid fermentation}}
M: {{c1::mixed acid fermentation}}
B: {{c1::butanediol fermentation}}
B: {{c1::butyric acid fermentation}}
A lotta people mmmmpphh, BB
might revise

See AnKing cards if present (and if discussed):

A: -
L (homo): genera: Streptococcus (all) and Lactobacillus (most)
L (hetero): -
P: Propionibacterium acnes, some anaerobic non-spore forming Gram + bacilli
M: genera: Escherichia, Salmonella, Shigella (within the Enterobacteriaceae)
B: genera: Klebsiella, Eneterobacter, Serratia (within the Enterobacteriaceae)
B: certain obligate anaerobes, Clostridium, Fusobacterium, Eubactrium spp.
Microorganisms that utilize pyruvic acid via {{c1::mixed acid}} fermentation would present a {{c2::positive}} <u>methyl red test</u> and a {{c2::negative}} <u>Voges-Proskauer test</u>

End products of this fermentation type:
1. lactic acid
2. acetic acid
3. succinic acid
4. formic acid
Microorganisms that utilize pyruvic acid via {{c1::butanediol}} fermentation would present a {{c2::negative}} <u>methyl red test</u> and a {{c2::positive}} <u>Voges-Proskauer test</u>

End products of this fermentation type:
1. acetoin (detected in VP test)
2. 2,3-butanediol
The {{c1::methyl red}} test is used to detect the ability of an organism to produce an acid from fermentation
The {{c1::Voges-Proskauer}} test is used to detect the ability of an organism to produce acetoin from fermentation

Which product of HMP shunt can be converted to pyruvate?

{{c1::glyceraldehyde 3-phosphate}}

What is this metabolic pathway that is most notably observed in Gram negative bacteria?

{{c1::Entner-Doudoroff pathway (ED pathway)}}
Lactose fermenters utilize lactose using 2 enzymes: {{c1::β-galactoside permease}} for cell membrane transport, and {{c1::β-galactosidase (aka lactase)}} for hydrolysis
{{c1::Silent}} genes are expressed only under certain conditions
{{c1::Constitutive}} genes are always expressed
recall: Housekeeping genes are genes that are constitutively expressed in <u style="font-weight: bold;">most or all tissues</u> (in eukaryotes)
{{c1::Inducible}} genes are expressed depending on the needs of the cell
how is this different from silent genes?
{{c1::Cryptic}} genes are usually not expressed during the life cycle of a microorganism but can be expressed in rare instances*
*: mutation, recombinaton, insertion process, etc.

Is bacterial chromosome ssDNA or dsDNA?

{{c1::dsDNA}}

Are plasmids ssDNA or dsDNA?

{{c1::dsDNA}}

Are plasmids essential for bacterial growth?

{{c1::No}}
Genes the code for virulence factors* are often located in the bacteria's {{c1::plasmid}}
virulence factors include: antibiotic resistance, toxins

Are plasmids passed down to daughter cells?

{{c1::Yes. They are also self-replicating}}
{{c2::Insertion sequence elements}} (~1kb) code for {{c3::transposase}} enzymes that allow it to <u>insert itself</u> in the middle of a gene, {{c1::inactivating::activating/inactivating}} it.
IS element is an example of a jumping gene
{{c1::Naked}} DNA is not associated with proteins, lipids, or any other molecule to help protect it (e.g. DNA released from burst cells)
Cells that can {{c2::take up naked DNA (transformation)}} are called {{c1::competent}}

Streptococcus pneumoniae
Neisseria gonorrhoeae
Haemophilus influenzae
Phage {{c1::induction}} refers to lysogens switching to the lytic cycle
{{c1::Fertility factor}} carries the genes for conjugative transfer and is located in the {{c2::plasmid}} DNA
if this F+ plasmid is incorporated into the cell's chromosomal DNA, it is called a Hfr strain
Bacteria prevent restriction enzymes from effecting their own DNA via DNA {{c1::methylation}}

Do the plasma membranes of prokaryotes contain carbohydrates?

{{c1::No}}
Eukaryotes, on the other hand, have glycolipids and glycoproteins
